awd_titl_txt: Ecological Sciences Education for All: Engaging Non-science Majors, Connecting Curriculum and Current events, Incorporating Cultural Relevance, and Advancing Systemic Change
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will support the 7th Life Discovery Conference on biology education, with a focus on Ecological Sciences for All. The Conference will be co-organized by the Ecological Society of America (ESA), the Botanical Society of America, and the Society for the Study of Evolution.  The project will support attendance of 50 participants from community colleges, primarily undergraduate institutions, and minority-serving institutions, as well as undergraduate preservice high school biology teachers.  The Conference will help participants learn about practical ideas and innovations that can be readily applied in classrooms, laboratories, and field sites.  It will also advance understanding of effective improvements in ecological sciences education at multiple levels. The overall goal is to place the biology education of science and non-science majors into the context of demographic, economic, and environmental changes in society. In doing so, it seeks to help to address ambivalence or hostility toward science that may occur in the classroom. 

The conference will extend education reform efforts propelled by Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Education a decade ago and highlight recent advances to provide a cohesive and modern approach to ecology education through ESA’s Four-Dimensional Ecology Education framework.  It will encourage the sharing of teaching ideas at any stage of development for constructive peer feedback, thus providing a professional environment for innovation in education practice. It will also offer participants an opportunity to join a community of practice through the post-conference Faculty Mentoring Network to incorporate ideas gained from the conference into the classroom.  Participant evaluations will assess three key aspects of the conference. First is the degree to which participants felt their goals were met in attending the conference. Second is how helpful the thematic tracks were and if participants found practical teaching ideas and strategies to incorporate the themes of the conference. Third is the degree to which participants can develop new collaborations. The three professional societies organizing the conference and conference collaborators will elevate the themes of the conference throughout their multiple fields of influence.  Increasing the used of more effective, inclusive teaching practices in biology classrooms can advance the nation toward the vision of a diverse and ecologically literate workforce and citizenry capable of contributing to the scientific study, management, and informed dialogue about our changing ecological systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project supported the 7th Life Discovery ? Doing Science Biology Education Conference which sought to provide a forum for organismal biology educators to engage in a discipline-based national conversation on the theme: Pushing Past Barriers: Ecological Science for All along four thematic tracks:

  • Engaging non-science majors
  • Connecting current events to curriculum
  • Incorporating cultural relevance for diverse audiences
  • Addressing levers for systemic change and implementation of evidence-based practices.

 75 participants, including 23 faculty from community colleges, minority-serving institutions and primarily undergraduate institutions attended the 7th Life Discovery ? Doing Science which was held Sept 30 - Oct 2, 2021 at the YMCA Estes Park, Colorado. The conference was collaboratively organized by representatives of three organizations:

  • Ecological Society of America (lead partner)
  • Botanical Society of America
  • Society for the Study of Evolution

 The conference has helped participants find resources and innovations to improve the way they approach the science of contemporary ecological issues with students and affirmed their commitment to teaching.  It also introduced ESA's four dimensional ecology education (4DEE) framework which builds on Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Education. The discussions on inclusive pedagogy has also built faculty awareness of the importance of reflecting on their own teaching styles and potential biases in the ways they introduce science topics, materials they select, and the way they design their courses. 

 Additionally, In Spring 2022, we organized the Life Discovery Faculty Mentoring Network (LD-FMN) as an extension of the LDC. Facilitated by two peer mentors from community colleges: Tamara Basham, Collin College and Jennifer Buntz, Central New Mexico Community College, 14 faculty participated in the FMN, including nine who attended LDC 2021.   The Faculty Mentoring Network is a professional development opportunity where participants met bi-weekly over a semester and worked collaboratively to share ideas and constructive feedback.

In 2023, four teaching resources were published in EcoEd Digital Library and QUBES Hub. They were disseminated to the wider ESA community as well as during the 2023 Life Discovery - Doing Science Education Conference reaching more than 3,000 educators.

Attendees reported that the project has helped them gain key ideas along critical levers of change including:

  • Practical ideas for Curricular innovation guided by Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Education and ESA?s Four-Dimensional Ecology Education (4DEE) framework
  • The role of faculty in developing the process of scientific thinking and science literacy among students 
  • Enhanced dialog on learning goals and best practices among community college and four-year institutions for transition success

The project supported participation of faculty from community colleges, minority serving institutions and primarily undergraduate institutions and facilitated networking across multiple institutional settings.  Its focus on non-science majors, current events, inclusive teaching and systemic levers, has contributed to more nuanced approaches to undergraduate biology education. The published teaching resources will extend the impact of the project to audiences who were not able to attend the conference.

These project and resources developed support the development of generations of a diverse and ecologically literate workforce and citizenry capable of contributing to the scientific study, management, and informed dialogue about our changing ecological systems.
